p: Insect exclusion had no effect on the aboveground biomass of goldenrod, regardless of biogeographic range or the presence of tansy (Figure 1). Contrary to predictions derived from the ERH, insect exclusion did not increase the biomass of goldenrod in either the native (USA) or non‐native (Hungary and Germany) range, regardless of the presence of tansy (Table 1). Importantly, however, goldenrod grew on average 19.6 g (± SE: 17.1, 22.3; t 759 = 11.0; p < .001) larger in Hungary and Germany than in the USA, with similar biomass in Hungary and Germany (Table 1). These trends corresponded to a significant main effect of biogeographic range, but no significant interactions involving biogeographic range or insecticide application (Table 1).
